title: btc_angela
author: btc_angela
content: For sure we have heard and seen the Los Angeles wild fire that has ravage and damage a lot of properties, including historical landmarks and houses of famous celebrities. But it can me thinking though, what if this affluent neighborhood has a lot of Bitcoin investors even early birds who have tons of BTC in their hardware wallets sitting in their homes?Or for those who had backup their private keys on metal seed storage? This could be a perfect example if they can really withstand extreme temperature. You can read reviews here: (https://jlopp.github.io/metal-bitcoin-storage-reviews/)So maybe it's time to rethink and revisit our ways of backing up our mnemonic phrases and private keys.

You can read reviews here: (https://jlopp.github.io/metal-bitcoin-storage-reviews/)So maybe it's time to rethink and revisit our ways of backing up our mnemonic phrases and private keys.Natural disaster causes losses in all things both humans and materials, so for sure, there will be some people who are caught up by this wildfire and lose their Bitcoin, although it is far better if you have something that has multiple protective features like a Bitcoin wallet, that the wallet seed can be saved in unlimited places and for someone using hardware wallet they might have probably saved their backup key in some online places even though that is not secured to do but at least there are ways that one can still encrypt the seed phrase in a file and with a disguised method that intruders will fine it hard to get what it is even though your online storage is compromised, so for that, the number of those that will lose they Bitcoin in this incident will be highly minimal.

comments.author: aoluain
comments.body: That thought crossed my mind in the last few days too.This is the time to remind people that its not enough to own a hardware wallet andbackup the seed its essential to backup in a way which preserves the seed throughfire and water and the best material is Marine grade Stainless Steel or Titanium.In terms of Stainless, Marine grade protects against water and corrosion and thethickness I would expect would determine how quickly is succumbs to fire and heat exposure.All my DIY plates are between 4 and 6mm thick.Of everything I own the most important thing is Bitcoin Seeds, Property shouldbe insured, documents can be replaced etc.

comments.author: Stalker22
comments.body: Man, that wildfire tearing through the fancy LA neighborhoods shows how nowhere's safe from natural disasters these days.  Makes you think - what if your house burns down with your hardware wallet inside? All those bitcoins, poof.  Even rich folks arent immune.  So you gotta have backups, my friends.  Store copies of your private keys or backup seeds somewhere else just in case and  nothing wrong with putting your crypto eggs in a few different baskets.  Spread it out.  Cause you never know when your place might go up in flames.  Then youll be wishing you had those backups.  Dont learn the hard way if you can avoid it.  Be smart and stay safe.  Protect your investment.

comments.author: True Dough
comments.body: Something to pounder: Prayers and best wishes for the wealthy people who are in a dangerous place now. Also, for those of us who lack the big wallets, we do not need to worry about big thefts or losses.

comments.author: Sanitough
comments.body: Let’s follow how banks secure their backups since they have guidelines for ensuring operations even during disruptions. For us, it’s like having a hard wallet. Banks don’t store their backups in just one location. That way, in case of a flood or fire, they can still access their data from another location and continue operating. For us, it’s similar, we can still access our crypto holdings because we’ve stored backups in different places.

comments.author: SatoPrincess
comments.body: You can store your seed phrase with washers, metal, or good old fashioned paper, but the most important thing is to keep them private and have backups in different locations. The topic of the risk of losing one’s seed phrase to natural disaster was discussed last year and I think the responses on that thread is very valid here:  Keeping or recovering seed phrases during or after a natural disaster

comments.author: Darker45
comments.body: That's why it's very important that you have multiple backups hidden in different locations. Fire, flood, tornado, and other disasters are more or less the same in that they could make you lose your backup. It doesn't even matter if your metal seed storage could withstand severe fire or pressure. The question is, after your house is burnt to the ground, after your house is washed away from ravaging flood waters, or dismantled by swirling air, or crushed after a strong earthquake, could you still locate that tiny piece of metal? You might not.

comments.author: pooya87
comments.body: That's a good point. Using more resistant medium for storing coins is one way but if you have to leave home and run away, it will still be left behind and in the ruins in the aftermath you may not be able to find it. Not to mention that with crime rates rising, it may be stolen! (they've already deployed the National Guard to try and prevent some of the lootings).So a better idea is to have an emergency plan where you can quickly take valuable "objects" with you in case of a disaster where you have to quickly evacuate. It could be albums, a hard drive, documents, etc. and of course your paper wallet.Keeping a backup in a different location is helpful as well. This is where the importance of encryption is highlighted.

comments.author: Jawhead999
comments.body: Not only having steel plate as your back up, I would consider to have something that you can always carry whenever you go, like this bracelet. Let's say there's a wildfire happened on your house, are you gonna enter your house and find your steel plate? I'm sure the firefighter and other people will push you to go back. But, if you wear this bracelet everyday, you don't have to worry if someday something bad happen on the place where you hide your seed phrase.

comments.author: promise444c5
comments.body: Firstly,there are no perfect way to store your backup but there are more secured way to store your backups  and you have mentioned  one of them in your  thread...However, LA case is not just a single house, it took out a lot of buildings  so even if the metal is heat resistant , you should consider rumbles and it will be very difficult to get it out in the midst of rumbles hence you might not be able to get access to it forever... only if lucky but it's a more secured way to store your backup and I belief if people have such backups with millions or hundreds of  thousand  worth of bitcoin then that must have been the fist thing to secure before abandoning the house unless they  can't recall "where"... so it's very important to know where you store your backups incase of emergencies.

comments.author: ranochigo
comments.body: Metal plates engraved with seeds are likely a pretty good solution, but you'll probably have to deal with the prospect of your house being buried under a huge rubble and being unable to find a small piece of metal in the middle. People with significant holdings are more likely to store them in several locations with a reasonable geographical distance apart.That, or just invest in a sturdy and fireproof safe that can withstand high temperatures. They likely have several things that they would like to protect anyways.

comments.author: Rikafip
comments.body: Quote from: btc_angela on January 10, 2025, 10:04:30 PMOr for those who had backup their private keys on metal seed storage? This could be a perfect example if they can really withstand extreme temperature. You can read reviews here: (https://jlopp.github.io/metal-bitcoin-storage-reviews/)Its certainly not a bad idea to have your seed phrase on  a metal plate, but still I wouldn't trust only this because good luck finding a small metal plate under all that burnt stuff, in case your house/apartment building burns to the ground.For that reason I think its a good idea to have your seedpharse safely stored at another location, if you have one.

comments.author: Kemarit
comments.body: I do agree with what most of the posters have said,1. back up your seed in another location, it's your call where you are going to put it2. invest on a metal steel plate as this is one of the best way to back up your seed, however, you should be the first one to be at your home if everything is clear and find it. Otherwise, if someone saw it and has a idea what it is, that person could steal your metal plate and sweep your Bitcoin

comments.author: passwordnow
comments.body: Man, I didn't thought of that. But there is a huge possibility that those affected ones saved first their private keys or wherever it is written or carved. I've watched several interviews and content near into that area and I've heard many of them say about Bitcoin so, there's really the chance that many of them are investors, early and new. And I hope that most of them saved their precious mnemonic phrases if ever they've foreseen that their neighborhood was going to be affected by that wildfire.
